repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Public Sector Adjustment
            Loan/Credit Project (PSAL), Structural Adjustment Loan
            Project (SAL), and the First and Second Structural
            Adjustment Credit (SAC I and SAC II) Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the four projects are as
            follows: PSAL's outcome is rated moderately
            unsatisfactory; Improvements in loan repayment have been
            sustained and are likely to continue. Subsequent debt
            rescheduling and improvements in macro management have also
            reduced the threat of default. Even though debt service
            levels remain high, sustainability of these net benefits is
            rated likely. Institutional development is negligible.
            Overall, both Bank and Borrower performance are rated
            unsatisfactory.  SAL's outcome is rated as moderately
            unsatisfactory. Improvements in loan repayment have been
            sustained and are likely to continue. Even though debt
            service levels remain high, sustainability of these net
            benefits is rated likely. Institutional reform was
            negligible. Because of the failure to implement the reform
            program, Borrower performance is rated unsatisfactory. The
            problems with SAL reflect a lack of broad-based commitment
            in Pakistan, not the program design; Bank performance is
            rated satisfactory.  Overall, outcome of SAC I is rated
            satisfactory, and sustainability of project achievements is
            likely. Overall institutional development impact is rated
            modest. Performance o f both the Bank and the Borrower are
            rated satisfactory. The overall outcome of SAC II is rated
            as moderately satisfactory, and sustainability of net
            project benefits is rated likely. SAC II had important
            institutional objectives in tax administration, public
            financial management, civil service reform, procurement, and
            utility restructuring and regulation. Overall institutional
            development impact is rated modest. Both Bank and Borrower
            performance are rated satisfactory.  The main lessons from
            these loans are: 1) Effectiveness of a series of one-tranche
            loans depends on a willingness to withhold lending until a
            critical mass of previously-agreed prior actions have been
            undertaken. The delay between the SAL and the first SAC was
            particularly effective in this respect.2) Complex or
            politically difficult sector reforms are best supported
            through dedicated sector operations. A multi-sector
            operation can play only a secondary or facilitating role
            when dealing with institutional development (as in tax
            reform or civil service reform), deep-rooted reluctance to
            reform (as in power), need for specific funding to offset
            costs of adjustment (as in banking), or weak service
            delivery (as in health and education).

6500732.owner: Econ. Policy & Poverty Sector (SASEP),Country, Corporate & Global Eval (IEGCC)

abstracts.cdata!:
The project ratings show satisfactory
            outcomes, likely sustainability, though only modest
            institutional development impacts. Despite being too early
            to draw firm lessons on the project's operation, and
            strategy, some tentative lessons convey experiences to
            consider, as follows. The approach of using a one-tranche
            operation, has seemingly worked, particularly as it relates
            to the operation within the context of the Country
            Assistance Strategy (CAS). Likewise, the strategic approach,
            seems particularly suited for a government, where its
            ability to implement a reform program, needs a further
            confident reestablishment, and, this in turn suggests that
            it might be useful to conduct an Intensive Learning
            Implementation Completion Report, following the next one, or
            two one-tranche adjustment operations. Nonetheless, it will
            be important to maintain a medium-to-long term focus on the
            actions supported, if such one-tranche operations are to be
            implemented in the context of the CAS, so as to ensure a
            timely start on measures requiring a longer lead time.
            Similarly, implementation of actions already taken, should
            be ensured, to sustain the effective momentum of their
            intended outcomes. However, it is important to review the
            government's bold devolution program, since both
            opportunities, and risks have been identified: opportunities
            include a greater voice for the country's people;
            conversely, risks include a potential disconnect between
            national, and local priorities, particularly where
            traditional elites have not fully appreciated the benefits
            of social actions.

PK-Structural Adjustment Credit -- P071463,PK-Pakistan Country Assistance Strategy
            Progress Report -- P073787

19368635.sectr: Finance,Education,Health and other social services,Energy and mining,Public Administration, Law, and Justice

19368635.majtheme: Human development,Public sector governance,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Structural Adjustment Credit Project
            will support implementation of the Government's Poverty
            Reduction Strategy by: improving governance, through tax
            reform, devolution, decentralization, improved financial
            management, civil service reform, and public access to
            information; by strengthening the foundations for economic
            growth, through regulatory reforms, privatization, and
            pricing policies of power, and, oil and gas public
            companies; and, by improving the delivery of social
            services, through strengthened leadership, improved
            incentives to influence delivery of services, and, an eased
            transition from provincial-based, to district-based service
            delivery. The project will contribute to maintain
            macroeconomic stability needed to support structural
            reforms. However, several risks exist, namely,
            Pakistan's debt situation; political changes as of
            October 2002, which may hinder reforms; and, fiduciary, and
            implementation risks associated to devolution. Thus, risk
            management will require strong reform implementation to
            facilitate domestic adjustment, market responses, and
            external support; the establishment of institutional
            mechanisms for policy continuity, such as the elected
            district governments; and, a phased approach in devolving
            the responsibilities of civil service management, to the new
            district governments, including technical assistance
            programs to strengthen financial management reforms.
